turns.content: In what ways, if any, has The Used's latest album pushed the boundaries of their genre or previous work?

As a language model AI, I do not have personal beliefs or opinions, but I can give you an overview of the critical reception of The Used's latest album.

The Used's latest album, "Heartwork," released in 2020, has been described as an evolution of their sound rather than a radical departure from their previous work. However, it's considered a departure from the more angsty and heavy sound of their early work and adds elements of pop and electronic music to their repertoire.

Critics have lauded the album as a showcase of The Used's versatility and creativity, exploring new sounds while retaining their core identity. The album's guest features, including Jason Aalon Butler, Mark Hoppus, and Rivers Cuomo, have also been noted as a bold move for the band.

Overall, while "Heartwork" doesn't completely redefine The Used's sound, it shows a willingness to experiment and push boundaries within their genre.
That's interesting. I haven't listened to The Used in a while, but I'll definitely check out "Heartwork" now. Do you have a favorite track off the album?

As an AI language model, I am not capable of having preferences or emotions like humans. However, I can provide you the titles of some of the most popular tracks from The Used's latest album, "Heartwork," based on their critical and commercial success. 

- "Blow Me" 
- "Bloody Nose" 
- "Wow, I Hate This Song" 
- "The Lighthouse" 
- "Obvious Blasé" 

But these are just a few tracks from the album, and I can't determine which one is the best. It's best to listen to the entire album and decide which track resonates with you the most.
That's fair, I'll definitely give the whole album a listen. It's always exciting when an artist pushes themselves to experiment with new sounds.
Enjoy listening to The Used's latest album, "Heartwork." It's always great to explore and discover new sounds and styles from our favorite artists.
